There's a lot to be said for your first section.

You're wrong, however, in your second section. Many, many physicians were over-prescribing fentanyl patches--too high does, too many at a time, for too long a period, for symptoms for which an opioid was not going to be particularly helpful--and certainly not for long.

When physicians' primary source of information on pharmaceuticals is pharma reps, rather than professional journals (and there is much research to support that that's the case), this is what happens.

Particularly when the physicians have no education, training, or experience directly applicable to appropriate prescribing of opioids.

Oh--and more injection sites are a critical need--keeps people alive until their primary health problem can be properly and helpfully addressed.

First thing, require every day in court to start at 8 am, not 10 am. One half hour lunches (one hour maximum), not two hours for lunch, and finish the day at 5 pm, not 3 pm. This would double the amount of time available in court, probably resulting in an immediate 70% increase in results, with the same amount of resources.

Second, require judges and prosecutors to sit through the summer like most working people. Three or four weeks holiday maximum. If you don't want to work fulltime, then we'll replace you with people who want to provide a full day's work.

Third, shed the stupid 18th century gowns and ancient technology and procedures. Start using modern technology to its fullest. No need to eliminate fundamental legal tenets.

Simply throwing more money at a broken, lazy system will not fix anything.

By the way large investment, low per-customer income means that, even if ISPs had gone there without government incentives - they would STILL have been a monopoly.
Because a large investment and low sales margine is the definition of a natural monopoly. It is NEVER worth it for a competitor to appear when those conditions hold - because the other company always has the advantage of having made part of their investment back already. Such cases the market can ONLY EVER be a monopoly.

So making it a government monopoly actually reduces the harm of the monopoly - because that means you can at least make some rules to limit how much it would be abused.
Chances are- in many places nothing would exist, and the others - there would be a monopoly just as there is now.

No, Stephen. God's church is never satisfied with the status quo. It's just that the church seeks to change the status quo through Kingdom living, not political advocacy.  Christians who believe that the policies of Barack Obama or Donald Trump are God's method for changing the status quo distort God's plan and character. 

Jesus changed the status quo by a life that led to death on a cross. When the disciples of John the Baptist came to inquire why He seemed uninterested in fulfilling His inaugural promise to change the status quo, Jesus responded with  displays of personal love and mercy toward the victims of sin - not strident protests to Caesar, and demands that Caesar reform the laws that perpetuated the social, institutional and cultural status quo. 

The Jewish leaders expected the Messiah to change the status quo and achieve justice for the Jewish people. They would resonate with today's Christian social justice warriors.

The De La Salle Christian Brothers were privileged to be the recipients of Bob's talents as he went about the design of the Chapel in the new addition to De La Salle College on Michigan Road in the early 60's. The gilded icon image of Christ the Teacher was cut into the beige brick wall  and visible from all sight lines.  There were anxious months for the Brothers before this design was presented to Cardinal O'Boyle,  Fortunately, he was an alum of a FSC run college and subsequently made an Affiliated member of our Institute. What Libby Unthank Tower advocates for is crucial, not least in light of what's happened to the rock 'n' roll bar scene in Eugene that produced the likes of the Searchin' Soul Blues Band in the late '60s and the Robert Cray Band and Curtis Salgado in the 1970s and how, according to Martin Scorsese, "Cinema is gone" (Register-Guard, 12/27, C4), for just two immediate examples. But it's also important to make explicit what Unthank Tower implies. For "culture" is not only music, books and our heritage. It is those patterns of meaning any group or society uses to interpret and evaluate itself and its situation. It is the symbolic and learned aspects of society transmitted not biologically but via social interaction. Nor can culture be reduced to, or explained away by, economic and political factor, though of course those factors certainly do influence -- without determining -- culture for good and ill, as Unthank Tower and the plight of rock 'n' roll and cinema demonstrate vividly.
